title: IAS Officer's Live-In Partner To Pay Rs 70 Lakh To His Wife, As Per Court Order
text:
When a husband cheats on his wife, he is obviously in the wrong, but what about the woman he is cheating on his wife with? Dr Ranjita Achom got married to Dr Konsam Shyamsunder Singh in 2009 and they have three children.

According to The Hindu, she filed for divorce from her husband in a Manipur court, after finding out about his live-in partner, Yambem Puni. She sought Rs 10 crore in damages for “loss of consortium and mental agony” caused by their illicit affair.

Dr Ranjita Anchom is an assistant professor at Imphal’s Jawaharlal Nehru Institute of Medical Sciences (JNIMS) and her husband, is an IAS officer.

The case was heard on September 13, when Dr Singh confessed to his illicit relationship with Puni. But he said that he had already given her a status of his ‘second wife’ as they completed a ‘Loukhatpa ceremony’ (which is recognised as marriage/acceptance ceremony, locally), in 2016.

But the court said that Puni can’t be registered as a second wife under the Hindu Marriage Act of 1955, as reported by the New Indian Express. 'Live-in relationship with a married person amounts to intentionally alienating one spouse from the other – it is an important tort – wife, and children of the married party can sue the other party to relationship for damages', the court said.

On October 18, the judge Y. Somorjit Singh ordered Puni pay Rs 70 lakh to legal wife - Rs 10 lakh for “causing mental distress”, another Rs 10 lakh for “lowering the reputation of the legal wife in the eyes of the society”, and Rs 50 lakh for “punitive or exemplary damages.”
